DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Yen Slip
DOC.TEXT: Uncertain prospects over interest rates in Japan and the United States, coupled with the Panama situation, slumped the dollar against the Japanese yen and share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today. The dollar closed at 143.67 yen, down 0.10 yen from Thursday's close of 143.77 yen. After opening at 143.67 yen, the currency ranged between 143.65 yen and 143.79 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, a 296.52-point loser Thursday, lost 175.11 points, or 0.45 percent, closing the week at 38,040.37. Masahiko Sahara, a dealer with Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd., said the market was ``unable to find the dollar's direction,'' squeezed by the issues of Japan's official discount rate and signs of easing U.S. monetary credit. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, reiterating his earlier stance of three days ago, told a news conference this morning that current price and monetary conditions in Japan do not require changes in monetary policy. But Hashimoto added monetary authorities will look at movements in currency and money markets in determining when to raise the key lending rate. Lower interest rates make a country's currency less attractive to investors. Yasushi Mieno, the new governor of the Bank of Japan, said in an interview with the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's largest economic newspaper, that a discount-rate hike would be needed to stem excessive price rises and stabilize the foreign exchange rate, the paper reported today. During a briefing Thursday on wholesale price trends, central bank officials said upward price pressures have been increasing over the last few months. A Bank of Japan official, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity, said higher prices for oil and natural gas, the yen's continued weakness and the effect of higher wages on prices in certain sectors, such as machinery, were threatening price stability. Earlier this week, news reports said the Bank of Japan planned to raise its official discount rate by 0.5 percentage points from the current 3.75 percent points some time this week. The Finance Ministry and central bank officials have denied any central bank action would be taken in the near future. The official discount rate, the rate the Bank of Japan charges on loans to commercial banks, influences other domestic interest rates. ``Speculation that the central bank now is considering to hike its key lending rate next year, probably in January or early February'' sent many investors reteating to the sidelines, said Sachiko Hata, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co. Investors were wary how the situation in Panama following Wednesday's U.S. military intervention in that Central American country would develop, she said. Ms. Hata said prospects that the U.S. monetary authorities would lower the nation's discount rate early next year also worked as a negative factor in the day's securities market.
